bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William C. Adamson, April 14, 1916

div1.p: [Carter] discusses a possible bill by Congress thanking Gorgas, Stevens and Goethals for their work.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William C. Adamson, April 14, 1916
div1.opener:
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.,
April 14, 1916.
Mr. Adamson,
House of Representatives,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Mr. Adamson:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of a letter enclosing Report No. 515,
House of Representatives, Without discussing this Report--
which to me seems better than the Bill it amends--let me, if I
may do so without offense, say one thing. I have talked with
many old Isthmenos, mainly civilians, since the passage of the
Bill of last spring, and can say that a bill giving the “Thanks
of Congress” to Colonel Gorgas: John F. Stevens and Colonel
Goethals, and nothing else, would have been considered by most
of them, as sufficient recognition of us, who had worked with
them. I, at least, who was promoted under the last Bill, would
have been better satisfied if the three chief men named above--
The two Chief Engineers and the Chief of the Sanitary Department--
had received the thanks of Congress and all the rest of the Bill
left out. The thanks of Congress should be sufficient acknowledge-
ment for any man without the addition of pecuniary or rank-increas-
ing rewards. It has rarely been given indiscriminately. There
seems every reason why Mr. Stevens--a civilian--should have re-
ceived recognition as well as we who are in the regular Services.
He was second to no one in the construction of the Canal.

I don't think this is an attempt to influence Congres-
sional action. I do not mean it as such. It is simply to let
you know how a number of the old Canal men feel on this subject.
I think I can speak for many of those who went down in the begin-
ning. I began work in May /04 and bore the heat and burden of
the work. There was really no risk to health and no hardship
to Americans after June 1906. In 1904 and 1915 there was both.
